    While Some Bonds Are Off Saving England, Others Help You Save For Retirement

    By Vestivise / on March 25th, 2017 / in Assets, Featured

    Problem: When we think Bonds, Daniel Craig shouldn’t be the first thing to come to mind!

    Similar to Stock Types, Bond Types tell you how your assets are split within the various Bond categories. Although generally, bonds are considered a safer investment than stocks, different Bond Types do vary in their levels of risk. Just like with stock types, knowing the types of bonds you are invested in is crucial for your understanding of the overall risk associated with your portfolio.

    What are Bonds

    The first step to understanding bond types is to first understand bonds. Bonds are a type of investment where the investor loans money to a government or company by purchasing that entity’s bonds. In exchange for making the purchase, the entity promises to repay the investor a sum of money larger than the amount they originally borrowed over a defined period of time when the bond matures (when the investor’s money is due). This benefits the borrowing entity (i.e. company or government) because they get money now to help grow their business or carry out a government function. It also benefits the investor who loans the entity the money because they get a return on their investment when they are paid back.

    Why are Bonds Safer than Stocks

    You might be wondering why bonds are considered safer than stocks. The reason for this is when you buy a company’s stock you are buying a part of the company. So how much money you make (or lose) hinges directly on how well the company is doing when you sell. On the other hand, when you buy a company’s bonds you are effectively buying their debt. This means that even if the company is having a tough year, as long as they have not gone bankrupt, you will get back the amount of money they promised you when you first bought the bond. Even in the event that the company goes bankrupt or gets sold, they will still have to take whatever money they have left and pay back their debts before distributing the remainder among the company’s owners. So in this case, as a bond holder you will get paid back before any of the stock holders can claim their portion of the company’s remaining assets. But keep in mind that it works both ways. In the event that the company does well, the stock holders stand to make more money than those who bought bonds since they took more risk by buying the stock.

    What are Bond Types

    Bond types are the categories that the bonds you own fit into. There are 6 bond types that you could see on your Vestivise Dashboard: Government, Municipal, Corporate, Cash, Derivative, and Securitized. The important thing to know when judging the risk present in your portfolio is the differences between bonds issued by governments and those issued by companies.

    Bonds issued by governments come in two types: Government bonds (bonds issued by national governments) and Municipal bonds (bonds issued by state or local governments). Bonds issued by companies come in many different types; the most popular of which is Corporate bonds, the kind we used in the example above.

    Why are Bond Types Important

    While there are other factors that play into a bond’s risk, such as how long you have to wait until the bond matures, knowing the bond type can help you understand your risk more than anything else. This is because it helps you identify who is borrowing your money.

    Generally speaking (at least in the U.S.) government issued bonds, especially those issued by the Treasury (national government), carry much lower risk than any of the 4 other types of bonds that are issued by companies. However, because they are safer, they don’t need to offer as high of a return to attract investors so returns from Corporate and other company bonds tend to be higher.

    Why this is the case boils down to a very simple reason: safety. Just like with any other investment, entities that are considered less likely to fail are safer to invest your money into.

    Let’s look at a quick example. Monica has a friend who is looking to buy a bond, let’s call him Joey. Joey comes to Monica with two options and asks for her advice. The first option is a Treasury bond that has a 2% yield (the amount of interest Joey would make on his investment when it matures). The second option is a bond offered by Joe Schmo’s Crab Shack that has a yield of 5%. Monica, knowing that Joey really hates risky investments, advises Joey to buy the Government bond and explains that the chance of Uncle Sam defaulting on the promise to pay Joey back is much lower than the chance of Joe Schmo not being able to deliver. Finally, being the great friend that she is, Monica reminds Joey that, regardless of which one he picks, the best way to curb against risk is to diversify his portfolio among a variety of different bond AND stock types!
